column1: Postal codes used in the United Kingdom are known as postcodes (originally
column2: postal codes). They are alphanumeric and were adopted nationally between 11 October 1959 and 1974
column3: having been devised by the General Post Office (Royal Mail). A full postcode is known as a "postcode unit" and designates an area with several addresses or a single major delivery point.The structure of a postcode is two alphanumeric codes
column4: the first having between two and four characters and the second
column5: three characters. First
column6: one or two letters indicate the postcode area
column7: followed by one or two digits signifying a district within that area. This is followed by a space and then a number denoting a sector within said district
column8: and finally by two letters which are allocated to streets or sides of a street. Postcode areas are often named for a major town or city—such as B for Birmingham—but may also be geographic in nature—such as HS for the Outer Hebrides.

column1: Each postcode area contains a number of post towns which are not themselves alphabetically denoted; however each will generally constitute one or more postcode districts. Example: a sizeable part of southern England is covered by the GU postcode area
column2: named after the town of Guildford. Guildford itself consists of postal districts GU1 and GU2. Nearby Woking
column3: a major commuter town—6 miles (10 km) away—is a post town within the postal district GU22. The central part of the town/city the postcode area is named after will have the number 1 e.g. B1 (Birmingham)
column4: LS1 (Leeds)
column5: M1 (Manchester). However
column6: other post towns within the area are then either treated alphabetically—particularly in London—e.g. Chingford on the north-eastern edge of London being E4
column7: whereas adjacent Walthamstow to the south being E17–or geographically—e.g. the Outer Hebrides area HS numbering the districts north to south.

column2: large post towns are numbered from the centre outward such that outlying parts have higher numbered districts
column3: but the disparate post towns within a postal area can be numbered based on various criteria—the town the postal area is named after excepted
column4: this always being 1. In particular
column5: one cannot reliably infer the centrality of a postcode district within a postcode area from the postcode alone.  For instance
column6: SE1 covers a large part of Central London south of the Thames whereas SE2 covers Abbey Wood at the far end of the Elizabeth Line. See postcode area.

column1: Postcodes have been adopted for a wide range of purposes in addition to aiding the sorting of mail: for calculating insurance premiums
column2: designating destinations in route planning software and as the lowest level of aggregation in census enumeration. The boundaries of each postcode unit and within these the full address data of currently about 29 million addresses (delivery points) are stored
column3: maintained and periodically updated in the Postcode Address File database.The initial system of named postal districts
column4: developed in London and other large cities from 1857
column5: evolved towards the present form: in 1917 London was split into broad numbered subdivisions
column6: and this extended to the other cities in 1934. Since the local government reorganisation of London in the 1960s
column7: parts of Greater London lie outside the London postal area. These include large parts of the "TW"

column1: As examples of the postcode system
column2: the postcode of the University of Roehampton in London is SW15 5PU
column3: where SW stands for south-west London; the postcode of GCHQ is GL51 0EX
column4: where GL signifies the postal area of Gloucester. The postal town can be a wide area and does not relate to a specific town
column5: county or region. GL51 is one of the postcodes for the town of Cheltenham (in Gloucestershire).

column2: deliveries can reach their destination using the house number (or name if the house has no number) and postcode alone; however
column3: this is against Royal Mail guidelines
column4: which request the use of a full address.

column1: The London post town covers 40% of Greater London. On inception (in 1857/8)
column2: it was divided into ten postal districts: EC (East Central)
column3: WC (West Central)
column4: N
column5: NE
column6: E
column11: and NW. The S and NE sectors were later abolished. In 1917
column12: as a wartime measure to improve efficiency
column13: each postal district was subdivided into sub-districts each identified by a number; the area served directly by the district head office was allocated the number 1; the other numbers were allocated alphabetically by delivery office
column14: e.g. N2 East Finchley delivery office
column16: N4 Finsbury Park delivery office etc. Since then these sub-districts have changed little.

column1: Some older road signs in Hackney still show the North East (NE) sector/district.
Following the successful introduction of postal districts in London
column2: the system was extended to other large towns and cities. Liverpool was divided into Eastern
column3: Northern
column4: Southern and Western districts in 1864/65
column5: and Manchester and Salford into eight numbered districts in 1867/68.In 1917
column6: Dublin—then still part of the United Kingdom—was divided into numbered postal districts. These continue in use in a modified form by An Post
column7: the postal service of the Republic of Ireland. In 1923
column8: Glasgow was divided in a similar way to London
column9: with numbered districts preceded by a letter denoting the compass point (C
column16: SE).In January 1932 the Postmaster General approved the designation of some predominantly urban areas into numbered districts. In November 1934 the Post Office announced the introduction of numbered districts (short postal codes) in "every provincial town in the United Kingdom large enough to justify it". Pamphlets were issued to each householder and business in ten areas notifying them of the number of the district in which their premises lay. The pamphlets included a map of the districts
column17: and copies were made available at local head post offices. The public were "particularly invited" to include the district number in the address at the head of letters.A publicity campaign in the following year encouraged the use of the district numbers. The slogan for the campaign was "For speed and certainty always use a postal district number on your letters and notepaper". A poster was fixed to every pillar box in the affected areas bearing the number of the district and appealing for the public's co-operation. Every post office in the numbered district was also to display this information. Printers of Christmas cards and stationery were requested to always include district numbers in addresses
column18: and election agents for candidates in the upcoming general election were asked to ensure they correctly addressed the 100 million items of mail they were expected to post. Businesses were issued with a free booklet containing maps and listings of the correct district number for every street in the ten areas.The ten areas were:

column2: Toxteth was Liverpool 8. A single numbering sequence was shared by Manchester and Salford: letters would be addressed to Manchester 1 or Salford 7 (lowest digits
column3: respectively). Some Birmingham codes were sub-divided with a letter
column4: such as Great Barr
column5: Birmingham 22 or Birmingham 22a
column6: as can still be seen on many older street-name signs.

column1: The Post Office experimented with electromechanical sorting machines in the late 1950s. These devices presented an envelope to an operator
column2: who would press a button indicating which bin to sort the letter into. Postcodes were suggested to increase the efficiency of this process by removing the need for the sorter to remember the correct sorting for as many places. In January 1959 the Post Office analysed the results of a survey on public attitudes towards the use of postal codes
column3: choosing a town in which to experiment with codes. The envisaged format was a six-character alphanumeric code with three letters designating the geographical area and three numbers to identify the individual address. On 28 July Ernest Marples
column4: the Postmaster General
column5: announced that Norwich had been selected
column6: and that each of the 150
column7: 000 private and business addresses would receive a code by October. Norwich had been selected as it already had eight automatic mail sorting machines in use. The original Norwich format consisted of "NOR
column8: followed by a space, then a two-digit number (which, unlike the current format, could include a leading zero), and finally a single letter (instead of the two final letters in the current format).In October 1965, Tony Benn as Postmaster General announced that postal coding was to be extended to the rest of the country in the next few years.On 1 May 1967 postcodes were introduced in Croydon. The many postcodes for central Croydon began with CRO"
column9: while those of the surrounding post towns with CR2
column10: CR3 and CR4. The uniform system of a set of three final characters after the space (such as 0AA
column11: known as the inward code) was adopted. This was to be the beginning of a ten-year plan
column12: costing an estimated £24 million. Within two years it was expected that full coding would be used in Aberdeen
column24: Southampton and the Western district of London. By 1967
column25: codes had been introduced to Aberdeen
column28: codes were introduced to the London Western and North Western postal districts. In December 1970
column29: much Christmas mail was postmarked with the message "Remember to use the Postal Code" although codes were used to sort mail in only a handful of sorting offices.During 1971
column30: occupants of addresses began to receive notification of their postcode. Asked in the House of Commons about the completion of the coding exercise
column31: the Minister of State for Posts and Telecommunications (whose role superseded that of Postmaster General in 1969)
column33: stated that it was expected to be completed during 1972. The scheme was finalised in 1974 when Norwich was completely re-coded but the scheme tested in Croydon was sufficiently close to the final design for it to be retained
column34: with CRO standardised as CR0 (district zero) thus removing the need to create a CR1 district.A quirk remained: the central Newport (Gwent) area was allocated NPT at a similar time to Croydon becoming CRO
column35: and surrounding areas were (as today) allocated NP1–NP8. NPT lasted until the end of 1984 when it was recoded NP9.Girobank's GIR 0AA was the last domestic postcode with a fully alphabetical outward code. That code no longer exists in the Royal Mail's PAF system
column36: but was taken over by the bank's current owners

column1: ==== Adaptation of earlier systems into national system ====
When the national postcode system was introduced
column2: many existing postal districts were incorporated into it
column3: so that postcodes in Toxteth (Liverpool 8) start with L8. The districts in both Manchester and Salford gained M postcodes
column4: so Salford 7 became M7 and so on (and similarly in Brighton and Hove
column5: both using the prefix BN). The old coding lives on in a small number of street signs with (for example) "Salford 7" at the bottom. In other cases
column6: the district numbers were replaced with unrelated numbers. In Glasgow many of its G-prefixed numbers are not used as C1 became G1
column12: and so on. In London (as postally defined)
column13: 1917-created postal districts are mapped unchanged to those of today but its much enlarged administrative area
column15: was created in April 1965. From that month the remaining 60% of Greater London's area has postcodes referring to 13 other post towns. Additionally
column16: there were too few postcodes to adequately cover districts in central London (particularly in the WC and EC areas)
column17: so these were subdivided with a letter suffix rather than being split into new numbered districts so as to retain the familiar codes.

column2: the Royal Mail licensed use of the postcode database for a charge of about £4000 per year. Following a campaign and a government consultation in 2009
column3: the Ordnance Survey released Code-Point Open
column4: detailing each current postcode in Great Britain together with a geo-code for re-use free of charge under an attribution-only licence (Open Government Licence as part of OS OpenData).

column1: ==== Postcodes linked to a variety of UK geographies ====
The Office for National Statistics (ONS Geography) maintains and publishes a series of freely available
column2: downloadable postcode products that link all current and terminated UK postcodes to a range of administrative
column3: health
column4: statistical and other geographies using the Code-Point Open grid reference.

column2: and are variable in length: ranging from six to eight characters (including a space). Each postcode is divided into two parts separated by a single space: the outward code and the inward code respectively. The outward code includes the postcode area and the postcode district
column3: respectively. The inward code includes the postcode sector and the postcode unit respectively. Examples of postcodes are "SW1W 0NY"
column4: "PO16 7GZ"
column5: "GU16 7HF"
column6: and "L1 8JQ".

column1: The outward code is the part of the postcode before the single space in the middle. It is between two and four characters long. Examples of outward codes are "L1"
column2: "W1A"
column3: "RH1"
column4: "RH10" or "SE1P". A few outward codes are non-geographic
column5: not divulging where mail is to be sent.

column1: The postcode area is part of the outward code. The postcode area is either one or two characters long and is alphabetical. Examples of postcode areas are "L" for Liverpool
column2: "RH" for Redhill and "EH" for Edinburgh. A postal area may cover a wide area
column3: for example "RH" also covers parts of north Sussex and "BT" (Belfast) covers the whole of Northern Ireland.

column1: The postcode district is one digit
column2: two digits or a digit followed by a letter.

column1: The inward code is the part of the postcode after the single space in the middle. It is three characters long. The inward code assists in the delivery of post within a postal district. Examples of inward codes are "0NY"
column2: "7GZ"
column3: "7HF"
column4: or "8JQ".

column1: The postcode sector is made up of a single digit (the first character of the inward code).
The postcode unit is two characters added to the end of the postcode sector. A postcode unit generally represents a street
column2: part of a street
column3: a single address
column4: a group of properties
column5: a single property
column6: a sub-section of the property
column7: an individual organisation or (for instance Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency) a subsection of the organisation. The level of discrimination is often based on the amount of mail received by the premises or business. Examples of postcode units are "SW1W 0NY"

column2: where A signifies a letter and 9 a digit:
the first part of a postcode can easily be extracted by ignoring the last three characters.

column1: The following central London single-digit districts have been further divided by inserting a letter after the digit and before the space: EC1–EC4 (but not EC50)
column2: SW1

column4: WC1
column5: WC2 and parts of E1 (E1W)
column6: N1 (N1C and N1P)

column2: V and X are not used in the first position.
J and Z are not used in the second position.

column1: The only letters to appear in the third position are A
column2: B
column3: C
column4: D
column5: E
column6: F
column14: U and W when the structure starts with A9A.

column1: The only letters to appear in the fourth position are A

column1: The final two letters do not use C
column2: I
column3: K
column4: M

column6: so as not to resemble digits or each other when hand-written.

column1: Postcode sectors are one of ten digits: 0 to 9
column2: with 0 only used once 9 has been used in a post town
column3: save for Croydon and Newport (see above).A postcode can be validated against a table of all 1.7 million postcodes in Code-Point Open. The full delivery address including postcode can be validated against the  Royal Mail Postcode Address File (PAF)
column4: which lists 29 million valid delivery addresses
column5: constituting most (but not all) addresses in the UK.The following regular expression can be used for the purpose of validation:

column1: All or part of one or more postcode districts are grouped into post towns. Larger post towns may use more than one postcode district
column2: for example Crawley uses RH10 and RH11. In a minority of cases
column3: a single number can cover two post towns—for example
column4: the WN8 district includes Wigan and Skelmersdale post towns.

column1: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man established their own postal administrations separate from the UK in 1969. Despite this
column2: they adopted the UK-format postcodes in 1993–94: Guernsey using GY
column3: the Isle of Man using IM
column4: and Jersey using JE.The independent jurisdiction of Sark was assigned a unique postcode prefix GY10 in 2011 to differentiate it from Alderney. The CEO of Guernsey Post
column5: Boley Smillie
column6: said "this has been a long time coming" and "... Sark should have had its own identity back then [when postcodes were adopted in 1993]".

column1: Some of the British Overseas Territories have their own postcodes or postcode systems:
These were introduced because mail was often sent to the wrong place
column2: e.g.
column3: for St Helena to St Helens
column4: Merseyside and Ascension Island to Asunción
column5: Paraguay
column6: and many online companies would not accept addresses without a postcode. Mail from the UK continues to be treated as international
column8: and sufficient postage must be used. Royal Mail's Heathrow centre collects all live underpaid mail for surcharging
column9: and there is a reciprocal arrangement with postal services around the world to collect. An agreed payment based on volumes is made

column1: Other forms of postage are collected at local mail centres
column2: but Heathrow collects those that still get forwarded to them. Bermuda
column3: the UK's most populous remaining overseas territory
column4: has developed its own postcode system
column5: with unique postcodes for street and PO Box addresses
column6: as have the Cayman Islands
column7: Montserrat and the British Virgin Islands. Montserrat recently introduced postal codes
column8: and a system has been under consideration in Gibraltar with the code GX11 1AA being introduced as the generic postcode for the territory in the interim. Postcodes are not used in the Turks and Caicos Islands—the TKCA 1ZZ designation is generally unknown.

column1: British Overseas Territories typically have a local or UK government postal system operator (see List of postal entities)
column2: even if a postal code is assigned by Royal Mail for internal UK routing.

column1: The British Forces Post Office (BFPO) provides a postal service to HM Forces separate from that provided by Royal Mail in the United Kingdom
column2: with BFPO addresses used for the delivery of mail in the UK and around the world. BFPO codes such as "BFPO 801" serve the same function as postal codes for civilian addresses
column3: with the last line of the address consisting of "BFPO" followed a space and a number of 1 to 4 digits.

column1: For consistency with the format of other UK addresses
column2: in 2012 BFPO and Royal Mail jointly introduced an optional alternative postcode format for BFPO addresses
column3: using the new non-geographic postcode area "BF" and the notional post town "BFPO". Each BFPO number is assigned to a postcode in the standard UK format
column4: beginning "BF1". The database was released commercially in March 2012 as part of the Royal Mail Postal Address File (PAF). A postcode is not required if the traditional "BFPO nnnn" format is used.

column1: Most postcodes apply to a geographic area but some are used only for routing and cannot be used for navigation or estimating distances. They are often used for direct marketing and PO boxes. Non-geographic postcode area BX is used solely for non-geographic addresses
column2: with codes independent of the location of the recipient. Some postcode sectors or districts are set aside solely for non-geographic postcodes
column3: including EC50
column4: BS98
column5: BT58
column6: BX1–BX9
column14: WV98 and JE4.  Also the first two numbers can be from the range 91 to 95 for businesses and a range 96 to 99 for Government departments.  The letters HQ for the last two letters could also it most likely is a non-graphical postcode of that Royal Mail holds the mail which a redirection
column15: bulk mail delivery or open and scan to email service is available.

column1: Girobank's headquarters in Bootle used the non-geographic postcode GIR 0AA. There is also a special postcode for letters to Santa/Father Christmas
column2: XM4 5HQ.Many non-geographic postcodes do not appear on Royal Mail's own online postcode finder tool or their Click and Drop online postage printing tool
column3: which can add to confusion when responding to organisations that use such addresses. Likewise
column4: delivery services or couriers other than Royal Mail may not be able to deliver to such non-physical addresses.

column1: Postcodes are allocated by Royal Mail's Address Management Unit and cannot be purchased or specified by the recipient. However
column2: Royal Mail sometimes assigns semi-mnemonic postcodes to high-profile organisations.Prominent examples are:

column1: The postcode printed on Business Reply envelopes (which do not require a stamp) often ends with the letters BR.
Postcodes are used to sort letters to their destination either manually
column2: where sorters use labelled frames
column3: or increasingly with letter-coding systems
column4: where machines assist in sorting. A variation of automated sorting uses optical character recognition (OCR) to read printed postcodes
column5: best suited to mail that uses a standard layout and addressing format.A long string of "faced" letters (i.e. turned to allow the address to be read) is presented to a keyboard operator at a coding desk
column6: who types the postcodes onto the envelopes in coloured phosphor dots. The associated machine uses the outward codes in these dots to direct bundles of letters into the correct bags for specific delivery offices. With a machine knowledge of the specific addresses handled by each postal walk at each office
column7: the bundles can be further sorted using the dots of the inward sorting code so that each delivery round receives only its own letters. This feature depends upon whether it is cost effective to second-sort outward letters
column8: and tends to be used only at main sorting offices where high volumes are handled.When postcodes are incomplete or missing
column9: the operator reads the post town name and inserts a code sufficient for outward sorting to the post town
column10: where others can further direct it. The mail bags of letter bundles are sent by road
column12: and eventually by road to the delivery office. At the delivery office the mail that is handled manually is inward sorted to the postal walk that will deliver it; it is then "set in"
column13: i.e. sorted into the walk order that allows the deliverer the most convenient progress in the round. The latter process is now being automated
column14: as the roll-out of walk sequencing machines continues.

column1: Integrated Mail Processors (IMPs) read the postcode on the item and translate it into two phosphorus barcodes representing the inward and outward parts of the postcode
column2: which the machines subsequently print and read to sort the mail to the correct outward postcode. Letters may also be sequentially sorted by a Compact Sequence Sorter (CSS) reading the outward postcode in the order that a walking postman/woman will deliver
column3: door to door. On such items the top phosphorous barcode is the inward part of the code
column4: the bottom is the outward.IMPs can also read RM4SCC items
column5: as used in Cleanmail
column6: a different format to the above.

column1: A newer system of five-digit codes called Mailsort was designed for users who send "a minimum of 4
column2: 000 letter-sized items". It encodes the outward part of the postcode in a way that is useful for mail routing
column3: so that a particular range of Mailsort codes goes on a particular plane or lorry. Mailsort users are supplied with a database to allow them to convert from postcodes to Mailsort codes and receive a discount if they deliver mail to the post office split up by Mailsort code. Users providing outgoing mail sorted by postcode receive no such incentive since postcode areas and districts are assigned using permanent mnemonics and do not therefore assist with grouping items together into operationally significant blocks. Walksort was discontinued in May 2012.

column1: There are approximately 1.7 million postcodes in the United Kingdom
column2: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.Each postcode is divided by a space into two parts. As mentioned above
column3: the first part starts with the postcode area and ends with the postcode district. The second part begins with a single digit
column4: which indicates the postcode sector
column5: and ends with the postcode unit.

column1: Postcode areas are also divided into several post towns
column2: which predate the introduction of postcodes
column3: with the London post town uniquely covering more than one postcode area.

column2: there are 124 postcode areas
column4: 987 postcode districts
column6: 192 postcode sectors
column8: 500 post towns. Addresses receiving large volumes of mail are each assigned separate "large user" postcodes. But most postcodes are shared by several neighbouring properties

column1: There are also significant numbers of discontinued (terminated) codes. Each month some 2
column2: 750 postcodes are created and 2
column3: 500 terminated.

column1: The Address Management Unit of Royal Mail maintains an official database of UK postal addresses and postcodes in its Postcode Address File (PAF)
column2: which is made available under licence for a fee regulated by Ofcom. The PAF is commercially licenceable and is often incorporated in address management software packages. The capabilities of such packages allow most addresses to be constructed solely from the postcode and house number. By including the map references of postcodes in the address database
column3: the postcode can be used to pinpoint a postcode area on a map. PAF is updated daily.On its poweredbypaf.com website
column4: Royal Mail publishes summary information about major changes to postcode sectors and postal localities (including post towns). Individual postcodes or postal addresses can be found using Royal Mail's Postcode and Address Finder website
column5: but this is limited to 50 free searches per user per day.

column1: A complete list of all current Great Britain postcodes
column2: known as Code-Point Open
column3: has been made available online (since 1 April 2010) by Ordnance Survey. Under the government's OS OpenData initiative
column4: it is available for re-use without charge under an attribution-only licence. The Code-Point Open list includes median coordinates for each postcode but excludes postcodes in Northern Ireland and the Crown dependencies. Unlike the PAF products provided by Royal Mail
column5: the Code-Point Open list does not include postal address text.

column1: === ONS Postcode Directory and National Statistics Postcode Lookup ===
The Office for National Statistics also produces postcode directories
column2: under similar licence terms to the OS product. Both the ONSPD and NSPL contain Northern Ireland postcodes
column3: with centroid coordinates in the OSI grid as opposed to the OSGB grid
column4: although Northern Ireland postcodes are subject to a more restrictive licence permitting internal business use only. Postcodes for the Crown Dependences are also included
column5: without co-ordinates. A further difference is that non-current postcodes and dates of introduction and withdrawal of postcodes are included.

column1: While postcodes were introduced to expedite the delivery of mail
column2: they are useful tools for other purposes
column3: particularly because codes are very fine-grained and identify just a few addresses. Among these uses are:

column2: to navigate to an address by street number and postcode

column1: By life insurance companies and pension funds to assess longevity for pricing and reserving
By other types of insurance companies to assess premiums for motoring/business/domestic policy premiums
To determine catchment areas for school places or doctors' surgeries

Finding the nearest branch of an organisation to a given address. A computer program uses the postcodes of the target address and the branches to list the closest branches in order of distance as the crow flies (or
column2: if used in conjunction with street-map software
column3: by road distance). This can be used by companies to inform potential customers where to go
column4: by job centres to find jobs for job-seekers
column5: to alert people of town planning applications in their area
column6: and a great many other applications.The phrase "postcode lottery" refers to the variation in the availability of services by region
column7: though not always because of postcodes.

column2: postcodes in some areas have become indicators of social status. Some residents have campaigned to change their postcode to associate themselves with a more desirable area
column3: to disassociate with a poorer area or to be associated with an area with a lower cost of living. In all these cases Royal Mail has said that there is "virtually no hope" of changing the postcode
column4: referring to their policy of changing postcodes only to match changes in their operations.Postcode areas rarely align with local government boundaries and a few straddle England's borders with Wales and Scotland. This has led to British Sky Broadcasting subscribers receiving the wrong BBC and ITV regions
column5: and newly licensed radio amateurs being given incorrect call signs.
